title: Between 4 October 2019 and 12 May 2020, how many states will fully ban the retail sale of vaping products?

Of those flavor bans, many were blocked by judges due to lawsuits. Recently no state has banned the sale of cigarettes. Despite the branding of e-cigarettes as safer, I think we can use the lack of full bans on cigarettes as a base rate for vaping products. The impetus for many of the current bans was the mystery surrounding vaping illness and the prevalence of young people vaping. With the new FDA ban on all flavored vaping products, raising the legal age to purchase e-cigarettes, and the CDC linking the vaping illness to vitamin E acetate often from illegal THC vapes, I believe the pressure to ban these products has abated."

There are 4 months left in this challenge, nothing will happen in this space in that timeframe.

Outside view: 
15 US states enacted bans on the sale of cigarettes from 1890 to 1927 [4] In February 2019 there were news articles about Hawaii considering banning the sale of cigarettes to anyone under the age of 100 to be phased in by 2024 [5]. Bans on cigarettes have mostly centered on banning where cigarettes can be smoked, like restaurants, public spaces, and work spaces. Some of these bans have now been extended to vaping products. Lobbying: Juul spent $1.2 million on federal lobbying during 2019Q3. Their lobbyists were fighting proposal to ban flavored e-cigarette pods, pushing legislation that includes provisions denying local governments the right to adopt strict vaping controls, and working to make sure bills to discourage youth vaping did not have stringent enforcement. [9, 10] Inside view: 
The FDA banned flavored vaping products with the exception of tobacco and menthol [1]. Trump signed a law in December that raised the legal age to purchase cigarettes, e-cigarettes, cigars and other tobacco products to 21. [1] Massachusetts issued a 4 month blanket ban on all vaping products in September. The temporary blanket expired Dec. 11. The ban was meant to allow time to develop permanent regulations that will ensure risks are known to consumers, address risks identified by the developing science, and ensure sellers are not skirting the new law and selling to kids. A new law set to take effect on June 1, 2020 is not a blanket ban, but instead limits the sale of flavored nicotine vaping (and tobacco) products, including menthol to ‘licensed smoking bars where they may only be smoked on-site.’ It also levies a 75% excise tax on e-cigarettes [2]. Michigan put an emergency ban into place Sept. 18 on nicotine vaping product in any flavor except tobacco. By Oct. 15 a judge put an injunction on the ban for 6 months.  New York on September 17 became the first state to implement a statewide ban on most flavored nicotine vaping products (excluding menthol). Before the ban was to go into effect on October 4, a court placed a hold on the ban.  Rhode Island banned the sale of flavored e-cigarettes. A judge allowed the ban to stand.  Montana sought to ban all flavored e-cigarettes, including those containing THC and CBD for 120 days, which would have taken effect on Oct. 22 but a Montana judge blocked the policy on Oct 19.  Washington health officials passed an emergency rule on Oct. 9 to ban the sale of flavored vaping products to last 120 days.  Oregon on Oct.  11 filed rules to forbid the sale of flavored nicotine and cannabis vaping products for 6 months. The policy was partially blocked by an appeals  In California the Governor issued an executive order on Sept 16 that allocated funds for a ‘vaping awareness campaign,’ calls on state agencies to develop recommendation for limiting the sales of vaping products to anyone younger than 21, and the sales of illegal or counterfeit vaping products. The governor said he would like to ban flavored e-cigarettes outright but could not do so through executive action. San Francisco became the first major US city to ban the sale of all nicotine e-cigarette products after a vote in November (went into effect in January 2020) [6].   There have been 2,602 lung injury cases that required hospitalization and 57 deaths linked to vaping. Vaping related ER visits peaked in September. In November the vaping illness was linked to vitamin E acetate [7, 8].  None of the state bans except for the short-term Massachusetts ban sought to ban the *sale* of e-cigarettes and instead focused on banning flavored products. Of those flavor bans, many were blocked by judges due to lawsuits. Recently no state has banned the sale of cigarettes. Despite the branding of e-cigarettes as safer, I think we can use the lack of full bans on cigarettes as a base rate for vaping products. The impetus for many of the current bans was the mystery surrounding vaping illness and the prevalence of young people vaping. With the new FDA ban on all flavored vaping products, raising the legal age to purchase e-cigarettes, and the CDC linking the vaping illness to vitamin E acetate often from illegal THC vapes, I believe the pressure to ban these products has abated.  It is possible another state will pass another short-term full ban if there were to be another spate of illnesses or deaths related to vaping. However given the fact that only one did it during the last health crisis in September, I think this probability will be low (5-10%). I will be putting the rest of the weight on no states banning vaping products.  [1] https://www.cnbc.com/2020/01/02/fda-issues-ban-on-some-flavored-vaping-products.html
[2] https://www.npr.org/2019/11/27/783400051/massachusetts-governor-signs-law-severely-restricting-flavored-tobacco-vape-prod
[3] https://time.com/5685936/state-vaping-bans/

[5] https://www.cnn.com/2019/02/04/health/hawaii-cigarette-ban-bill-trnd/index.html
[6] https://www.forbes.com/sites/kenrickcai/2019/11/06/san-francisco-vaping-ban-results/#340cdfc06bb7
[7] https://www.nytimes.com/2019/11/08/health/vaping-illness-cdc.html?searchResultPosition=10
[8] https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/health/vaping-illness-tracker-evali.html
[9] https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/on-small-business/juul-spent-record-12-million-lobbying-as-regulators-stepped-up/2019/10/22/2a0dbc52-f4de-11e9-b2d2-1f37c9d82dbb_story.html
[10] https://www.nytimes.com/2019/04/28/health/juul-lobbying-states-ecigarettes.html

Downgrading forecast.  MA signs new law (https://thehill.com/policy/healthcare/472271-mass-governor-signs-groundbreaking-vaping-flavor-ban-into-law)  that restricts the sale of all flavored nicotine vaping products and bans menthol cigarettes as of June 1.   Flavored vaping products can be sold and consumed in licensed smoking bars.  (Imagine the cost of that license!) Also includes a 75% tax on e-cigarettes and health insurers have to cover tobacco cessation programs.   I suspect other States may watch this as a potential model to copy or avoid.

Increasing the probability of bins 2, 3, and 4 in light of news that the AMA is pushing to “ban the sale and distribution of all e-cigarette and vaping products, with the exception of those approved by the F.D.A. for tobacco cessation purposes and made available by prescription only" - this would, in effect, be a full ban on retail sales of vaping products since "no vaping product currently on the market has been approved by the F.D.A. as a 'smoking cessation' device" [2]. I find this development very surprising given that a recent report by the CDC indicates that vaping products specifically containing vitamin E acetate are likely cause of the vaping-related illnesses/deaths nationwide [3] - however, this nevertheless does increase the likelihood of outright state bans on retail sales of all vaping products. Between 4 October 2019 and 12 May 2020, how many states will fully ban the retail sale of vaping products? Hattip to @JC4841 for analysis showing that conditions change in light of new unexpected information.

Updating in light of a new report out today by the CDC [1] that indicates that vitamin E acetate, which is mostly found in illicit THC vaping substances (see my previous post), is probably the cause of vaping-related illnesses. This probably means that states are extremely unlikely to impose outright bans going forward, especially in light of the fact that none other than MA (a judge has already partly lifted this state's ban) have so far in the time where we have been unsure of the cause. More targeted bans are far more likely than all-encompassing bans now that we know the apparent cause. [1] https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/volumes/68/wr/mm6845e2.htm

Decreasing the probability of bin 1 and increasing that of bins 2 and 3 given recent news that China, "citing health concerns for minors," is banning online sale of e-cigarettes [1]. I am surprised by this development, especially given that the CDC in the US has found that it is specifically THC-containing products that seem to  have caused the vast majority of vaping-related illnesses [2]. Nevertheless, because of this recent ban by China, I find it more likely that more U.S. states will ban the retail sale of vaping products but I still think that such outright bans are very unlikely.  [1] https://www.nytimes.com/2019/11/01/business/china-vaping-electronic-cigarettes.html
[2] https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/volumes/68/wr/mm6843e1.htm?s_cid=mm6843e1_w

As @dlaiocean mentioned, the CDC has come out with a new update on the likely culprit of vaping-related illnesses and deaths: "As of October 22, 2019, a total of 1,604 cases of EVALI, including 34 deaths, were reported to CDC. Based on data collected as of October 15, 2019, use of tetrahydrocannabinol (THC)-containing products in the 3 months preceding symptom onset was reported by 86% of patients." [1] 86% is a very significant figure, and is almost certainly even higher since underreporting of THC use is very likely since non-medical marijuana is still illegal in most states.  So, now that it's extremely likely that the culprit of vaping-related illnesses/deaths has been identified, state authorities will have even less of a reason to impose a blanket ban on the retail sale of vaping products. Rather, products that contain THC are likely to be targeted instead. [1] https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/volumes/68/wr/mm6843e1.htm?s_cid=mm6843e1_w
CNN reportedd "Deaths linked to vaping often involved THC products, not nicotine, CDC says." Increase zero probability. https://www.cnn.com/2019/10/28/health/cdc-vaping-death-data-mmwr/index.html

Juul just voluntarily suspended the sale of fruity-favored e-cigarettes due to the imminent Federal ban of such products (I.e. a partial ban for this question) [1].  This will negate the need for a partial ban from individual states. It will also reduce the argument for a full ban from the states. [1] https://www.cnbc.com/2019/10/17/e-cigarette-giant-juul-suspends-sales-of-fruity-flavors-ahead-of-looming-ban.html

Court of Claims suspends MI vaping ban; Gov vows to go to Supreme Court: https://www.wlns.com/news/whitmer-to-seek-supreme-court-ruling-to-keep-vaping-ban/.  Maintaining low likelihood of all-out vaping ban.

E-cigarettes have been introduced in the US since 2004 [1].  Currently CDC estimated that there are 6 million vaping users [1].  No illness or death has been attributed to vaping until April 2019. The mortality of this unknown illness is about 2% (about 26 deaths out of 1299 illness) [2].  CDC is currently investigating the cause of this illnesses and death. 

This sudden outbreak of vaping illnesses and death is intriguing and it points to possible links to recent changes in vaping products.  There are indications that suggest chemicals (THC, Vitamin E acetate and others) added to vaping oil are potential  causes [2], but it will take time for the CDC investigation to arrive at a conclusion, probably till May next year. Currently Massachusetts is the only state that fully bans vaping products (but the legislation was passed before the start date of this question and therefore does not count).  Five states (Rhode Island, Washington, Minnesota, New York and California) have partial bans.  The partial bans are partly due to the uncertainty in their causes and pressure from the vaping industry.  It is likely that additional partial bans in other states will happen as the vaping illness does not appear to be diminishing. However, full bans of vaping products are unlikely, with the exception of a couple of liberal states, such as California.  This assessment would change if CDC finds vaping itself alone is the cause (which I assess to be unlikely because of the past extensive usage of vaping with no reported illness in the last 15 years). [1]  https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Electronic_cigarette
[2]  https://www.cdc.gov/tobacco/basic_information/e-cigarettes/severe-lung-disease.html

• Reasons for more bans:
		○ May 2020 is a long time away
		○ They could find a serious health hazard
		○ 1 state has already banned it
		○ It's increasingly a flashpoint issue
	• Reasons against more bans:
		○ Base rate for this is low for states banning anything like this (eg tobacco products).
                ○ Only the most liberal states (like 10 in total) would probably ever do it

Vaping with with flavor unknown chemical interaction has caused deaths in a very short interval where smoking impact is very long term. So vaping incidents are an immediate threat that is instant news. That is why I feel that many states will ban the vaping with anything other than nicotine.
Regulations on quality and sourcing will kick in.

Feels unlikely that other states are going to impose a ban, most are going with restricting and regulating the marketplace as a less disruptive solution. That said, there are other 49 states and there is no way I am taking the time to research them all so I'm just going to assume that one or two other states are going to really consider banning vaping products and save myself a few hours.

I am making this forecast as I believe that there will be a number of states, most likely those on the East and West Coasts, that will ban the sale of vaping products.  I do however believe that only a few states will ban the sale of these products as it has been proven to be the sale of illegal vaping products with vitamin E oils contained in them that are actually the cause of the outbreak of deaths in adolescents.  We have never banned the sale of any tobacco products, so I believe that it would not be in the best interest of tobacco corporations who hold a significant foothold in the U.S. government to actually ban these products as they provide a considerable amount of revenue to the industry as well as being a new form of smoking in the future that could change the way people think about nicotine and nicotine products.

https://talkbusiness.net/2019/10/ag-rutledge-calls-on-ebay-to-remove-e-nicotine-devices-products/
Senate President Jim Hendren, R-Gravette, and Sen. Missy Irvin, R-Mountain Views, who chairs the Senate Public Health committee, have called for a special session to consider ways to stem the vaping epidemic, which has led to health issues and potential deaths. Hendren has proposed the School Safety Act, which would levy a 67% privilege tax on e-cigarettes like the one levied on many other tobacco products. Cigarettes in Arkansas are taxed at a rate of $1.15 per pack. The bill would add e-cigarettes to the Arkansas Clean Indoor Air Act of 2006, which prohibits smoking indoors in public places. It also would ban e-cigarette advertising on outdoor billboards located within 1,000 feet of a public or private school or playground, and make other restrictions. Last month, the House and Senate Public Health, Welfare and Labor Committees voted to adopt an interim study on the issue. Rutledge hosted the first Youth Vaping Summit for parents, medical professionals, educators and legislators at Arkansas Children’s Hospital on Monday. A similar summit will take place Wednesday (Oct. 9) at Bentonville High School.
It is more likely that states will wait to see the result of the Massachusetts experimental ban before placing similar bans.
Court upholds MA ban for now.  Another hearing on the 15th. Provides encouragement for other States considering a ban.
Michigan is the only state I think is particularly likely to add a total ban. With the industry lobby getting stronger I don't see too many states doing a total ban.

- Highly taxed in some states (CA, IL, DC, PA for example.)
- Cigarette smoking declining fairly rapidly but 85% of young adults (18-29) have tried e-cigs
- Vaping replaces cigarettes - tax revenue needed by States 
- Ultimately, vaping will be deemed safer than cigarettes (if you fully ban vaping, kids turn to cigarettes and it's the counterfeit vaping cartridges causing the deaths)
- Counterfeit flavored vaping products increase, more deaths due to the ban
- Retail store owners bringing lawsuits in NY and MA
- I think there may be 3 States capable of a full ban based on current fears vs. known facts, 2 have already banned flavors so low likelihood they go full board like MA did
- Will we learn much more in the next few months?  Have to factor in the unknowns that could come to light into next year
- Let the lobbying begin…
Updating based on further reading. So far only Massachusetts has implemented a full ban. Several other states have chosen instead just to ban flavoured products.

It looks like most of the problems with vaping have been with illicit marijuanoid crap.  Massachusetts has a nascent marijuana industry to protect.  This causes one to suspect that the next state(s) to outlaw all vaping will also be weed-legals.  By now, the growers in most such states will be better organized and funded for lobbying than the vapewallahs, so let's start with one or two.  I'd go with more except for the limited time this Q allows, given most state legislative calendars.  (And if I were you, I'd pay no attention to me.  This prediction is based on very close to zero actual data.)
